  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
petar_chervenski
Sent: Wednesday, February 25, 2009 8:09 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Neuron Output Conservation of Enery



If we assume that the energy being fed to the network is the magnitude 
of the inputs, then it becomes clear why such an approach is not 
applicable in most ANN models. Any weight above 1.0 will make the 
signal stronger and any weight below 1.0 will make it weaker. Weights 
close to 0.0 will make the signal disappear. This is the way ANNs 
ignore information. Suppose you have an ANN with all weights set to 0. 
The output you will get may be static all the time, but the lack of 
signal doesn't mean there is lack of *information*, since the NN is
essentially trained to ignore everything. 
The mathematical model that is used to represent artificial neural 
networks doesn't cover conservation of energy or anything like that. 
In fact, why you would need such a thing at all? Is there a merit in 
the approach? I am interested.

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, Eric
Mohlenhoff <eric.mohlenhoff@...> 
wrote:
>
> From my (probably limited) understanding of neurobiology, such a
> conservation of energy principle would not be applicable to the 
model
> of neurons firing. At least not in the sense that I believe you are
> describing.
> 
> 'Energy' as it were, is not really 'transferred' between any given
> neurons in such a system. Neurons only interact via 
neurotransmitters
> being released into and absorbed from the synaptic cleft between 
said
> neurons. Electrical energy (which I gather is to what you are
> referring) is confined to within a particular neuron itself. In a
> properly functioning neuron, this energy is neither received nor
> transmitted. In fact, (and I may be mistaken here, so somebody 
correct
> me if I am) I beleive that the effects of such neurological diseases
> as multiple sclerosis are actually precipitated by this electrical
> energy escaping the cell due to a degeneration of the myelin sheath
> that would normally cover the axon of the cell, along which the
> electrical signals within the cell travel from dendrite to axon
> terminal.
> 
> If it were the case that a conservation of energy principle was
> applied to such a model, and the electrical signals *were* being
> transmitted cell-to-cell, this would impose a ceiling on the number 
of
> layers possible in the network, degree of recursion in feedback
> networks, etc. due to what would be inevitable signal degradation to
> the point of no longer being usable. That is unless there was also 
the
> provision for 'repeater' cells/nodes in the network (a concept that 
I
> have personally not encountered as of yet).
> 
> Basically, the energy that is 'distributed' across connecting 
neurons
> actually comes from within the cell (insert complex/detailed
> discussion about mitochondria, phosphorylation, etc. here... haha),
> itself being a function of the type, amount, and possibly other
> yet-to-be-discovered properties of the neurotransmitters (and 
possibly
> other chemicals as well) that are within the synaptic cleft at the
> time that the firing was initiated.
> 
> A better analogy (I believe) would be the one proposed by a large 
body
> of the literature: a single neuron is a black-box function. It takes 
a
> given input (absorbing neurotransmitters from the synaptic cleft) 
and
> produces an output (releasing neurotransmitters into the synaptic
> cleft). Any conservation of energy principle is resetricted to being
> applied to the processes occurring within the cell itself, because 
in
> this (limited) sense the cell is acting as a closed system for that
> electrical energy.
> 
> Hope this helps,
> 
> Eric
> 
> PS Anyone, feel free to correct me if any of this is off-base or 
just
> plain wrong too. I'm just going by my cursory understanding of these
> things, and so could be mistaken about some of this.
> 
> On Wed, Feb 25, 2009 at 8:39 AM, Raymond Von Wahlde
> <rvonwahlde@...> wrote:
> > I have a question relating to the analogy of the interconnected 
nodes
> > of an artificial neural net as neurons. A node receives inputs 
that
> > are fed into an activation function. The activation function 
"fires"
> > an output somewhat comparable to a synapse firing. As implemented 
in
> > ANN's, the same output value (its "energy" as it were) from the 
node is
> > fed through weighted links to other nodes. What would be the 
effect of
> > imposing a sort of "conservation of energy" principal on the ANN?
> >
> > Isn't it the case that in an actual neural net, when a neuron 
fires its
> > total energy is distributed somehow to its connecting neurons. The
> > total energy received by the connected neurons can not be more 
than the
> > energy generated by the sending neuron. What if in an ANN, the 
value
> > coming from a node was split evenly between the outgoing links? 
And
> > for the receiving nodes, the sum of the weighted inputs could not
> > exceed the total energy generated by the sending nodes. Would 
there be
> > any benefit to forcing this restriction on an ANN?
> >
> >
>
